VII. W (wamy (cyccmst qzocomlsmnemess (ond furorldlmossffi-iv. 1-17.

(1) The cause of quarrelling is that each man seeks to gratify his own selfish impulses, and to snatch his neighbour's portion of worldly good—iv. 1, 2.

(2) No satisfaction can be thus obtained. Even our prayers can give us no satisfaction if they are infected with this worldly spirit. —iv. 3.

(3) God demands the service of the whole heart, and will reveal Himself to none but those who yield up their wills to His—iv. 4-6.

(4) Therefore resist the devil, who is the prince of this world, and turn to God in humble repentance.—iv. 7-10.

(5) Cease to find fault with others. Those who condemn their neighbours condemn the law itself, and usurp the office of Him, the Lord of life and death, who alone has the power and right to judge.—iV. 11, 12.

(6) Worldliness is also shown in the confident laying-out of plans of life without reference to God.-iv. 13-17.
